revisions.rev:
{{Infobox election | election_name = United States Senate elections, 1918 | country = United States | flag_year = 1912 | type = legislative | ongoing = no | previous_election = United States Senate elections, 1916 | previous_year = 1916 | next_election = United States Senate elections, 1920 | next_year = 1920 | seats_for_election = 34 of the 96 seats in the [[United States Senate]] | majority_seats = 49 | election_date = November 5, 1918 | image1 = | party1 = Republican Party (United States) | last_election1 = 42 seats | seats_before1 = 45 | seats_after1 = 49 | seat_change1 = {{increase}} 4 | popular_vote1 = | percentage1 = | swing1 = | image2 = | party2 = Democratic Party (United States) | last_election2 = 54 seats | seats_before2 = 51 | seats_after2 = 47 | seat_change2 = {{decrease}} 4 | popular_vote2 = | percentage2 = | swing2 = | title = Majority Party | before_election = Democratic Party | after_election = Republican Party }} The '''1918 U.S. Senate election''' occurred on November 5, 1918 coinciding with the midpoint of [[Woodrow Wilson]]'s second term as [[President of the United States]]. The [[Republican Party (United States)|Republican Party]] gained control with a slim 2-seat majority after picking up a net seven seats. The change in control was particularly important, since it meant that the Republicans were in a position to deny entry of the United States into the [[League of Nations]]--the centerpiece of Wilson's post-war foreign policy. Republicans gained seven seats: * [[Lawrence C. Phipps]] (CO) * [[L. Heisler Ball]] (DE) * [[Joseph M. McCormick]] (IL) * [[Arthur Capper]] (KS) * [[Selden P. Spencer]] (MO) * [[Henry W. Keyes]] (NH) * [[Irvine Lenroot]] (WI)--won in a special election Democrats gained one seat: * [[David I. Walsh]] (MA) == Separate election: April 2, 1918 == {| class=wikitable ! State ! Incumbent ! Party ! Result ! Candidates |- | [[List of United States Senators from Wisconsin|Wisconsin]]
Special: Class 3 | [[Paul O. Husting]] | {{party shading/Democratic}} | Democratic | {{party shading/Republican}} | Incumbent died October 21, 1917
